clues.clue: Charred floor tiles form spiral scorch marks, consistent with fire-element flight bursts.
A feather burned halfway through lies beside an extinguished torch — same pigment as Bifang’s plumage.
Smoke residue reveals traces of copper and oil, suggesting controlled ignition rather than wildfire.
The hall’s braziers were recently relit despite the ban on open flames after the eclipse ritual.
A small molten trail leads toward the outer corridor, indicating something aflame departed hastily.
Lightning scars run down the shrine’s stone columns, though no storm was recorded that night.
A single hoofprint the size of a man’s head is embedded in the mud outside the shrine gate.
The wooden drums of the shrine are split in half as if struck by thunder from within.
Villagers reported hearing rhythmic booms matching Kui’s one-footed gait before dawn.
Fragments of a shattered thunder charm were found lodged in the shrine’s roof tiles.
Blue feathers coated in divine pollen were scattered among the sacred lotus.
A trail of shimmering dust leads from the pond to the northern wall, suggesting rapid aerial descent.
Petals singed by friction heat imply repeated low-altitude flight.
A cracked jade pendant inscribed 'Messenger of the West' was retrieved from the garden’s fountain.
Two different avian call patterns were heard the night of the ceremony — one calm, one frantic.
Deep claw marks gouge the altar’s base, angled as if tearing upward from within.
Traces of human and beast blood mingle at the center stone; both partially crystallized by heat.
A talisman fragment bears the word 'Justice' written backwards — Qiongqi’s symbol of inverted morality.
Villagers claim a beast laughed during the eclipse thunder, echoing from the altar’s chamber.
An iron chain snapped clean through; its break shows signs of brute force rather than corrosion.
Nine intertwined serpentine grooves carved into the temple basin pulse faintly when exposed to moonlight.
Residual venom stains on the altar pool surface test positive for ancient toxin markers.
A ritual jar sealed with lead bears a warning: 'Do not unbind before the tide wanes'.
Several small fish float lifeless, their bodies unburned yet bloodless.
A whispering vibration under the temple floor suggests something vast still moves below.
Dusty scrolls are mis-shelved — all on the topic of spirits serving humans.
White fur strands cling to a ladder leading to the forbidden archive balcony.
Ink stains form distinct paw-shaped prints across several ritual manuscripts.
A witness described a creature 'mimicking human speech' arguing near midnight among the stacks.
A torn parchment references a deal between the ape-spirits and the Fox Clan.
Horse-like hoofprints with deep talon impressions appear at intervals along the mountain trail.
Wind-bent grasses form circular depressions, evidence of powerful wingbeats.
A messenger’s seal carved in bone was found cracked beside a cliff drop.
The sound of flapping wings mixed with a human voice was reported during the storm.
A dropped satchel contained half a celestial map marking the eclipse’s trajectory.
Faint perfume and paw prints encircle the summit’s ritual stone.
A broken mirror charm lies beside the path — fox magic often uses reflection illusions.
A trail of golden fur leads toward the ridge where moonlight is strongest.
Fragments of silk garments found — likely humanoid transformation attire.
Witnesses recall a melodic voice chanting alone under the eclipse before screams erupted.
